Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the workshops "Workshop in Analysis and Probability" that will be held on the campus of Texas A&M University during the period, July 2 - August 10, 2012, and the summers of 2013 and 2014. The ongoing Workshop in Analysis and Probability at Texas A&M University brings together senior and junior researchers and graduate students in several areas of analysis and probability as well as researchers in other fields (such as geometry and theoretical computer science) in order to broaden the education of the younger participants and to promote interaction among researchers in various fields. The Workshop also sponsors three day conferences (SUMIRFAS-Informal Regional Functional Analysis Seminar), Concentration Weeks, and mini-conferences. These conferences include introductory lectures designed to acquaint junior researchers and non experts with the basics of an area as well as advanced lectures for experts.

The Workshop activities have a wide impact by providing intellectual stimulation for all participants as well as giving an opportunity to a diverse group of junior participants to increase the breadth and depth of knowledge and to interact with senior researchers in several areas of mathematics. There is also significant outreach to applied mathematics and computer science. Indeed, a very important aspect of the Workshop is to promote cooperation among researchers in different fields, and every Concentration Week involves participants from experts in two or more research areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Workshop brought together senior and junior researchers and graduate students in several areas of analysis and probability as well as some researchers in other fields such as geometry and theoretical computer science with the goal of broadening the education of the younger participants and of promoting interaction among researchers in different areas. The Workshop featured the Concentration Weeks "Recent Advances in Harmonic Analysis and Spectral Theory" (2012), "Frame Theory and Maps Between Operator Algebras" (2012), "Dynamics, Geometry, and Operator Algebras" (2013), "Free Probability" (2013), "Groups, Groupoids, and Dynamics" (2013), and "From Commutators to BCP Operators" (2015), along with yearly installments of the three-day conference SUMIRFAS (Summer Informal Regional Functional Analysis Seminar) and around ten individual seminar talks each summer. The Concentration Weeks included introductory lectures designed to acquaint junior researchers and non-experts with the basics of a discipline as well as advanced lectures for experts. The Concentration Week "Recent advances in Harmonic Analysis and Spectral Theory" gathered two groups of experts, those specializing in complex and harmonic analysis and those working in the spectral theory of differential operators and mathematical physics, with the aim of studying new relationships and widening further participation in these areas in the United States. The Concentration Week "Frame Theory and Maps Between Operator Algebras" promoted the nascent connections between frame theory and the study of maps between operator algebras by bringing together researchers in the two subjects so that they could learn from one another and build networks of potential collaborators. The Concentration Week "Dynamics, Geometry, and Operator Algebras" provided a novel meeting ground for recent evelopments involving connections between nuclearity, nuclear dimension, group C*-algebras and crossed products, topological and measurable dynamics, algebraic dynamics, entropy, dimensional ideas from coarse geometry, and K-theory, with the goal of stimulating interdisciplinary collaboration and expanding perspectives within areas such as noncommutative geometry, ergodic theory, and the classification theory of nuclear C*-algebras. The Concentration Week "Free Probability" made a major contribution in the synthesis and dissemination of the state of the art in the theory of bi-freeness recently initiated by Voiculescu. The Concentration Week "Groups, Groupoids, and Dynamics" contributed to an understanding of the relationship between several new developments in group theory, groupoids, dynamics, and operator algebras by assembling a host of different topics (for example, sofic entropy theory and orbit equivalence, generator problems in ergodic theory, von-Neumann-algebraic rigidity, and amenability via dynamics) in both a novel combination and a concentrated format. The Concentration Week "From Commutators to BCP Operators" promoted connections between several different themes in operator theory which have been driving recent progress in the subject, and included such topics as quasidiagonality, commutators of operators, and invariant subspaces.

The Workshop activities have had a broad impact by providing intellectual stimulation for all participants as well as giving an opportunity to a diverse group of graduate students and junior researchers to broaden their education across a wide range of topics in functional analysis and related fields (operator theory, probability theory, ergodic theory, statistical mechanics, harmonic analysis, Banach spaces, operator algebras, free probability, noncommutative geometry, and operator spaces) and through a variety of formats, from the lectures series and research talks in the Concentration Weeks to the individual seminars where participants presented and discussed their work in a less formal setting.
